subclusters.subcluster_name: Epigenetic and Chromatin Remodeling Senescence Theory
p16INK4a-Mediated Muscle Stem Cell Senescence Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) driving inflammation, metabolic dysregulation, and chronic tissue dysfunction.
Emphasizes SASP and tumor suppressor pathways (p53-p21, p16INK4A-pRB) regulating senescence and its dual role in physiology and pathology.
Highlights SASP, immune clearance/evasion, and the dual beneficial/detrimental roles of senescence in tissue remodeling and chronic inflammation.
Focuses on SASP's role in cancer and aging, including extracellular vesicles as SASP components influencing tumor microenvironment and inflammation.
Details SASP-driven secondary senescence via IGFBP7 signaling modulating insulin/IGF pathways, emphasizing paracrine senescence induction.
Describes SASP impact on bone and immune systems, linking chronic inflammation and immunosenescence to aging via secretory phenotype.
Focuses on cell cycle arrest by p21/p16 and SASP secretion disrupting tissue integrity and promoting systemic aging.
Covers senescence as a causal driver of aging via SASP, tissue disruption, and therapeutic targeting of senescent cells.
Emphasizes SASP's dual role in tumor suppression and promotion, with senescence induced by multiple stressors.
Focuses on p53 and p16 pathways inducing senescence and SASP secretion altering tissue microenvironments.
Describes senescence as stable arrest with SASP secretion impacting tissue regeneration and aging phenotypes.
Highlights SASP as a systemic molecular aging signature promoting chronic inflammation and aging phenotypes.
Links senescence markers (p16INK4a, HMGB2) with SASP and aging, showing causal role of senescent cells in functional decline.
Focuses on SASP-driven inflammation and paracrine senescence, with therapeutic modulation of SASP to attenuate aging.
Describes stress-induced premature senescence and SASP-driven chronic inflammation accelerating aging, especially in HIV context.
Emphasizes extracellular vesicles as SASP components mediating paracrine/endocrine senescence signaling and aging propagation.
Focuses on senescence and SASP in aging and Alzheimer's disease, with senolytic clearance improving pathology and function.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Epigenetic and Chromatin Remodeling Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Centers on large-scale clustered transcriptional silencing and epigenetic mechanisms underlying senescence and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Epigenetic and Chromatin Remodeling Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on epigenetic regulation (DNA methylation, histone mods, chromatin remodeling) controlling senescence onset and maintenance.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Epigenetic and Chromatin Remodeling Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes epigenetic repression of INK4a/ARF locus by Polycomb proteins regulating senescence and aging phenotypes.
Focuses on replicative senescence driven by telomere shortening and the Hayflick limit as a fundamental aging mechanism.
Emphasizes p53 family regulation of mitochondrial metabolism, ROS, and energy defects driving senescence and systemic aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Epithelial Cell Senescence and Tumorigenesis Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on epithelial cell senescence as adaptive stress response with p16/RB pathway, SASP, and tumor-promoting escape mechanisms.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: p16INK4a-Mediated Muscle Stem Cell Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Details p16INK4a regulation by Slug transcription factor controlling muscle stem cell senescence and regenerative decline.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: p16INK4a-Mediated Muscle Stem Cell Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes loss of reversible quiescence and p16INK4a-driven geroconversion causing muscle stem cell senescence and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Neuronal Senescence via REST and Autophagy Dysfunction Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on REST deficiency impairing autophagy, activating p53-p21 axis, and inducing senescence in post-mitotic neurons.
